body:
I wanna pick everyone’s brains about Jo Jorgensen, the libertarian presidential candidate for 2020. She seems like she has a way better chance than Gary did, and I personally will be voting for her. Even if she doesn’t win, I think she’s going to make a HUGE impact on the stigma of voting third party.

What’re your thoughts on third party votes, the libertarian party, and JoJo’s chances at winning?
body_html:
I wanna pick everyone’s brains about Jo Jorgensen, the libertarian presidential candidate for 2020. She seems like she has a way better chance than Gary did, and I personally will be voting for her. Even if she doesn’t win, I think she’s going to make a HUGE impact on the stigma of voting third party.

What’re your thoughts on third party votes, the libertarian party, and JoJo’s chances at winning?
title: Discussion: The potential for JoJo to win the election

body:
she would stand a chance if the libertarian party hadn't shackled her to spike cohen. no one is going to seriously elect that guy. it's a shame because she is wickedly intelligent, articulate, and seeks to promulgate sensible policies - often splitting the baby between dems & republicans. i'm a lifelong libertarian, but i'm going to have to start taking more of an interest in the libertarian party because they should try to treat these things like they care at all. it should have been weld/johnson, not the other way around. it should be jorgensen/any breathing competent person who is not insane. but they couldn't do that for us. 

she is the best candidate, but i'll be voting for trump as a necessary voice of opposition. i need to send a message to the left that the current climate is unacceptable. it's not a lesser of two evils thing for me. it's a moral imperative to make sure that the left doesn't cancel free speech and debate. 

great question

author.bio_html: GM of +NBA, +DCcomics and +comicbooks

body:
I think it'll be next to impossible for any third party candidate without national name recognition to make any significant progress towards actually winning.

What becomes interesting is when you look at a 3rd party candidate siphoning votes away from one of the primary two candidates which leads to them losing an election that they may have won without that third party interference.  This was shown in 1992 with Ross Perot potentially taking away too many Republican votes from Bush and leading to Clinton winning. People also argue it happened in 2016 with Jill Stein, Gary and Hillary.

So I don't think JoJo is winning, or even breaking Perot's record in the popular vote, but she could definitely siphon enough votes to impact the election in some way.
body_html:

This was shown in 1992 with Ross Perot potentially taking away too many Republican votes from Bush and leading to Clinton winning. People also argue it happened in 2016 with Jill Stein, Gary and Hillary.

So I don't think JoJo is winning, or even breaking Perot's record in the popular vote, but she could definitely siphon enough votes to impact the election in some way.

body:
>What’re your thoughts on third party votes, the libertarian party, and JoJo’s chances at winning?

"Voting third-party is literally throwing your vote away." Cool story, bro. I'd rather throw my vote away than give it to a tyrant on either side.

"Lolbertarians - muh roads, police, fire department, 'we live in a society!'" Virtually all of those things are local/state government functions, at least if we're following the Constitution (I know, L O L). What the Federal government has to do with those things, and why it's taking money to give to the states to subsidize the states in state functions (again, ***if*** we're following the Constitution - lol!), I have no fucking clue.

Jojo's chances at winning? Absofuckinglutely NONE. She's an outspoken badass whose ideals align more with mine than Creepy Uncle Joe or The Donald, so she's getting my vote too.

body:
I don't like Trump at all but Biden is even more authoritarian and further left. He would be a dictator if he could, plus he can barely remember his own name anymore. Not saying Trump wouldn't do the same, but he at least recognizes *some* individual rights and a limited amount of free market.

The problem is both sides have it rigged so that only they stand any chance of winning. There are even laws in some areas prohibiting anyone but Democrats and Republicans. But what I want to know is how they so easily fool everyone into following this agenda.

author.bio_html: GM of +NBA, +DCcomics and +comicbooks

body:
Without getting into my personal politics, I generally vote with whoever aligns with more of my personal beliefs. Obviously with our two party system, there is no "a-la-carte" option. Both sides generally want to politicize people to believe everything they say is right and everything the other guys say is wrong, but the reality is that people are mostly shades of gray. In my experience anyone who just automatically fully just believes what their political party tells them to believe is either dumb, has an agenda, or is lying to themselves. 

So at the end of the day, we're probably not going to change the two party system overnight, so I feel I'm best off voting with whoever has most or more of my personal interests and beliefs in their platform. Trying to find the person who checks every single belief box you have will be next to impossible, you might as well start your own political career at that point.
body_html:

So at the end of the day, we're probably not going to change the two party system overnight, so I feel I'm best off voting with whoever has most or more of my personal interests and beliefs in their platform. Trying to find the person who checks every single belief box you have will be next to impossible, you might as well start your own political career at that point.

body: I'd agree with them booing her, not because driver's licenses are a bad idea (but the fees need to be based on **actual cost** of materials and time to provide the service - "for-profit government" is completely fucked from the start, at all levels), but because again, **state function** and she as a Federal official (if elected President) should have nothing to do with them. The only possible nexus the Feds should have to driver licensing is making sure states abide by the True Faith & Credit clause and honor each other's licenses.
body_html: I'd agree with them booing her, not because driver's licenses are a bad idea (but the fees need to be based on actual cost of materials and time to provide the service - "for-profit government" is completely fucked from the start, at all levels), but because again, state function and she as a Federal official (if elected President) should have nothing to do with them. The only possible nexus the Feds should have to driver licensing is making sure states abide by the True Faith & Credit clause and honor each other's licenses.
